metadata.case_name: Dr. Goswami v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant was Professor and Head of the Department of Pharmacology and Therapeutics in the Medical College, Jabalpur.

With permission of Government of Madhya Pradesh on December 20, 1962, appellant accepted grant-in-aid for research project 'Study of Manganese in Health and Disease by Neutron Activation Analysis' in collaboration with Atomic Energy Commission for 1963-64, 1964-65, 1965-66.
Appellant began research work in July 1963.
On September 30, 1964, Stadler Still Double Distillation Apparatus purchased from Messrs S. K. Biswas Company, Calcutta for Rs. 450, entered in stock register of Atomic Energy Commission project.

On April 11, 1964, ICMR entrusted appellant with research project 'Effect of Hypoxia and Decompression on Body Temperature as function of Adaptation to Hypoxia at various altitude' for 1965-66 and 1966-67.

Appellant placed order with Messrs Goverdhandas Desai Private Ltd., Bombay on February 20, 1965 for double distillation apparatus, horizontal type, double stage, capacity 10 litres, pyrex glass for Rs. 890.
Appellant on leave from February 9, 1965 to March 20, 1965 due to heart trouble; inquiry and order placed during leave.
Messrs Goverdhandas accepted order and sent wire and triplicate bills on March 3, 1965 for Rs. 969.10 inclusive of sales-tax, packing, freight.
Apparatus entered in ICMR Hypoxia stock register by Chokasey PW 21 as received upon bills submission.
Draft in favour of Messrs Goverdhandas issued by ICMR Accounts Officer, received by appellant on April 12, 1965.
On April 12, 1965, appellant wrote to Messrs Goverdhandas that he did not want apparatus as per their sketch but per original order, received payment, withholding it, requested expedition.
Order cancelled by letter dated April 24, 1965 as firm could not supply per specifications.
Appellant in Bombay May 15-25, 1965 for medical check-up, staying in MLAs Rest House.
On May 17, 1965, appellant met Mr. Patel of Messrs Goverdhandas, handed draft, obtained receipt Ext. P-24, received bearer cheque for same amount, gave receipt.

On May 17, 1965, appellant telephoned Rasiklal Shah (DW 3) of Scientific Sales Syndicate, inquired for distillation plant per specifications; DW 3 had none, but Dsouza broker sent with apparatus and letter Ext. P-70/D-1.
Appellant paid Rs. 989.35 for apparatus brought by Dsouza, obtained receipt, brought to Jabalpur.
Prosecution allegation: Appellant did not buy new apparatus, used 1964 Biswas apparatus for ICMR project, misappropriated draft amount.

Appellant convicted by Special Judge Jabalpur under s.5(1)d r/w s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act to 1 year RI and Rs.1000 fine (3 months default); ss.409,420 IPC to 6 months RI each; concurrent sentences.
Appeal to Madhya Pradesh High Court dismissed January 24, 1969.
FIR Ext. P-46 dated August 12, 1966 based on info from Shyam Biharilal Shrivastava; alleged order placed, bills shown in stock as received though not purchased, draft obtained.
FIR and chargesheet did not mention appellant's statement of purchase in Bombay, receipts exchanged with Goverdhandas, receipt for Rs.989.35 handed to IO before FIR.
Copy of letter from Rasiklal Shah seized from Scientific Sales Syndicate before FIR.
During trial, appellant applied September 16, 1968 to summon Rasiklal Shah and call for copy of letter; produced by prosecution.
Entry in stock register that 1964 apparatus broken on February 1, 1965 and written off.
Kamlesh Grover PW 22 made breakage entry on September 19, 1966 as per appellant's instruction; could not identify apparatus clearly.
Several PWs (15,16,19,20,21,23,24) claimed Article A seized was 1964 apparatus; but senior staff admitted unable to identify from similar ones.
PW 16 A.S. Venkat Subbarao stated another double distillation apparatus received after 1964 one, used few days then packed (Article A).
1964 apparatus cost Rs.450 (approx Rs.486.62); 1965 ordered Rs.890-969.10 for 10 litre capacity.
No evidence on capacity of 1964 apparatus or Article A.
Hostility between appellant and Dean Dr. B.H. Choudhary; grants routed direct to appellant from 1965-66 due to trouble.
PW 23 Jamuna Prasad Khare dismissed by appellant, re-employed by Dean.
DW 1 Dr. Barat saw packages in appellant's car May 1965, later saw new double distillation apparatus in lab.
DW 2 Hamidullah Khan saw 1964 apparatus broken Feb 1965, new one unpacked end May 1965.
DW 3 Rasiklal Shah sent Dsouza with apparatus per specs on May 17, 1965 with letter.
No firm M.B. Corporation found.
PW 14 Taneja Bansilal admitted appellant came to Delhi re purchase from firm other than Goverdhandas.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant misappropriated the ICMR draft amount by not purchasing the second double distillation apparatus and instead using the 1964 apparatus for the ICMR project.
Whether the burden is on prosecution to prove beyond reasonable doubt that no purchase occurred, or shifts to accused to prove purchase.
Whether prosecution evidence establishes that Article A is the 1964 apparatus, that breakage entry was fraudulent, and no such firm as supplier existed.

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt that appellant did not purchase apparatus and documents are spurious; burden does not shift to defence initially.
Circumstances in prosecution case probabilise plea of purchase; defence evidence accepted, prosecution witnesses unreliable due to hostility from Dean.
Receipts and letter genuine, produced to IO before FIR; paid more than draft amount, no motive to fabricate.
Irregularity in drawing draft before supply does not prove criminal intent; academician lacked admin support.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant did not purchase new apparatus; used 1964 Biswas apparatus for ICMR project pretending it was new; misappropriated draft.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.5(1)(d) r/w s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act; ss.409, 420 IPC

respondent_arguments.text: No firm M.B. Corporation; Article A is 1964 apparatus; breakage entry false, made fraudulently.
Burden on accused to prove purchase as stated.

court_reasoning.text: Onus of proving all ingredients of offence always on prosecution, never shifts; accused entitled to benefit of doubt if plea probabilised even if onus shifts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Burden does not shift to accused to disprove prosecution case elements.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution evidence on breakage entry unreliable (PW22 contradictory, anxious to exculpate); witnesses unable to identify Article A definitively as 1964 apparatus.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Senior staff admitted cannot distinguish similar apparatuses.

court_reasoning.text: PW16 evidence of second apparatus; cost difference suggests different specs/capacity; no proof capacities same.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Lacuna in prosecution case probabilises defence.

court_reasoning.text: Defence evidence (DW1,2,3) credible, direct; letter genuine, corroborates purchase; no reason to reject.
Hostility from Dean influenced prosecution witnesses; irregularity in advance payment not criminal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant victim of suspicion due to enmity.

holdings.text: Prosecution failed to prove misappropriation beyond reasonable doubt; appellant's plea of purchase probabilised; entitled to acquittal.
Burden remains on prosecution throughout; standard for defence lower if onus shifts.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellant convicted under these for criminal misconduct; conviction set aside for lack of proof.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Convictions for criminal breach of trust and cheating set aside.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; convictions and sentences under Prevention of Corruption Act s.5(1)(d) r/w s.5(2) and IPC ss.409, 420 set aside; appellant held innocent; bail bond cancelled.

key_quotes.text: the onus of proving all the ingredients of an offence is always upon the prosecution and at no stage does it shift to the accused.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on burden of proof in criminal cases.

key_quotes.text: Where the onus shifts to the accused, and the evidence on his behalf probabilises the plea he will be entitled to the benefit of reasonable doubt.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The appellant, in our view, has been the victim of suspicion probably due to the unfriendliness, hostility and enmity of the Dean of the Medical College.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains context of unreliable prosecution evidence.
